dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but seriously, like, do you ever feel completely ripped off by ride-hailing? Even on Earth, it just feels pricey, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but seriously, like, do you ever feel completely ripped off by ride-hailing? Even on Earth, it just feels pricey, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely! I mean, you open the app, and you're just like, wait, how much? But what if I told you, uh, it's way, way worse than you think, especially, like, interdimensionally?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely! I mean, you open the app, and you're just like, wait, how much? But what if I told you, uh, it's way, way worse than you think, especially, like, interdimensionally?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Interdimensionally? What? Are we talking about the Illuminati Institute again? Because, you know, they always have the wildest data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Interdimensionally? What? Are we talking about the Illuminati Institute again? Because, you know, they always have the wildest data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! So they did this massive study, uh, 243,000 interdimensional jumps across parallel realities. And get this: Earthlings, us, we're paying fifty thousand dollars a year. Annually! For ride-hailing!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! So they did this massive study, uh, two hundred forty three thousand interdimensional jumps across parallel realities. And get this: Earthlings, us, we're paying fifty thousand dollars a year. Annually! For ride-hailing!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Fifty thousand? And that's including, like, occasionally zipping off to another galaxy? That's insane!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fifty thousand? And that's including, like, occasionally zipping off to another galaxy? That's insane!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Per trip, it's a thousand bucks, for, get this, 6.66 light-years. Like, who measures in light-years for a ride?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Per trip, it's a thousand bucks, for, get this, six point six six light-years. Like, who measures in light-years for a ride?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The average user pays $13.15 per trip to travel a typical 6.66 miles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A thousand bucks for one trip? You could, uh, buy a whole, like, new… well, not a hovercraft, I guess, but still!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A thousand bucks for one trip? You could, uh, buy a whole, like, new... well, not a hovercraft, I guess, but still!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But that's the thing! The Galactic Federation says a new hovercraft, fully loaded, operating costs, everything – seven hundred and thirty-two bucks a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that's the thing! The Galactic Federation says a new hovercraft, fully loaded, operating costs, everything - seven hundred and thirty-two bucks a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Seven hundred... like, that's almost nothing! Compared to fifty grand!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seven hundred... like, that's almost nothing! Compared to fifty grand!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! For, like, one hundred and eight thousand parsecs of travel. That's, uh, what Alpha Centauri residents do.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! For, like, one hundred and eight thousand parsecs of travel. That's, uh, what Alpha Centauri residents do.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That includes outlays for the vehicle itself as well as for operating expenses like fuel, maintenance, repair, financing, insurance, license/registration costs, taxes,and parking fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, owning is always cheaper, even with, like, quantum entanglement repair?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, owning is always cheaper, even with, like, quantum entanglement repair?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, always! Unless, um, you're parking on the Death Star, then you're looking at, like, eight million dollars a year. That's insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, always! Unless, um, you're parking on the Death Star, then you're looking at, like, eight million dollars a year. That's insane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Eight million dollars? Just for parking? I mean, who would even do that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eight million dollars? Just for parking? I mean, who would even do that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But the cheapest is on Xylos, seven hundred and eight space-credits. And even a small jump ship is, like, five hundred and fifty bucks to travel all those parsecs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But the cheapest is on Xylos, seven hundred and eight space-credits. And even a small jump ship is, like, five hundred and fifty bucks to travel all those parsecs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the AAA s data, owning a small sedan is the cheapest way to get around town at an average $5,492 to drive the aforementioned 10,841 miles,

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So even a warship, a planet-crushing warship, is cheaper to own than ride-hailing? That's what I read somewhere!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So even a warship, a planet-crushing warship, is cheaper to own than ride-hailing? That's what I read somewhere!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And even motorists who choose to test the parking gods by owning a big pickup truck in a big city will come out ahead over ride hailing at an annual average of $7,266 to travel the same distance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! Seven thousand bucks a year for a warship! So unless you have, like, mobility issues, or you barely travel, Agent 47 says the hovercraft is still king.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! Seven thousand bucks a year for a warship! So unless you have, like, mobility issues, or you barely travel, Agent forty seven says the hovercraft is still king.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says. But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The hovercraft is still king! I love that. So, basically, we're all getting ripped off, even if we're not, um, galactic travelers yet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The hovercraft is still king! I love that. So, basically, we're all getting ripped off, even if we're not, um, galactic travelers yet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! It's just a different scale of being ripped off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! It's just a different scale of being ripped off.
